Other stuff
Section in progress. Things that may be missing or understated in current materials.

Working on text analysis modeling to analyze citation patterns in methodology across social sciences as part of postdoc duties
Attending a grant writing workshop in the Fall, focus on preparing an application for an NSF-equivalent grant in Canada
Dissertation data collection combines text analysis and supervised learning to create most up to date data set of Brazilian local anti-corruption audits
Dissertation got poster award at Latin American Polmeth 2019
Cool places I have interviewed but not taken jobs at that may make people feel like they need to hire me before someone else does:


Penn State, University of Konstanz, University of Birmingham, Howard University, William & Mary, KDI School of Public Policy and Management, Carlos III-Juan March Institute of Social Sciences, University of Melbourne


Went to EITM at Emory in 2019
Have experience mentoring an undergrad RA. Used it as an excuse so we could both learn text analysis. Student got job as data consultant after college. I claim all the credit
Last 3 years have been marked by: Pandemic, parenting, moving, escaping from hurricane, immigration troubles, family illness. This is the first summer since 2020 without a major life thing going on. Feel free to weave that in your assessment of my productivity if you feel it may help

Open Rank Search in Political Methodology - Department of Political Science - Cornell UniversityLetters: Jake, Matt, Michelle  Deadline: September 10, 2024  Delivery: Receive email  Notes: Search committee Tom Pepinsky (chair), Peter Enns, Bryn Rosenfeld. We are interested in candidates whose research uses modern statistical methodology to answer substantive research questions in political science, or whose methodological research deepens our understanding of quantitative political methodology, broadly understood (e.g., statistics, computational methods, causal inference, etc.). The successful candidate will teach courses in statistical methods and research design at the graduate and undergraduate levels.  
 
Open-rank Professor in Political Methodology - Department of Political Science - Massachusetts Institute of TechnologyLetters: Jake, Matt, Michelle  Deadline: September 15, 2024  Delivery: Receive email  Notes: NA  
 
Assistant Professor in Computational Social Science - Department of Political Science - Stony Brook UniversityLetters: Jake, Matt, Michelle  Deadline: September 16, 2024  Delivery: Interfolio  Notes: Michael Peress search committee chair. The department is interested in applicants with expertise in applying big data methods, computational methods, or advanced statistical methods to problems in political science.  
 
Assistant Professor in Data Analytics - Department of Political Science - Tulane UniversityLetters: Jake, Matt, Michelle  Deadline: September 16, 2024  Delivery: Interfolio  Notes: Virginia Oliveros is in the committee, she mentioned the NLP/network/machine learning requirement is not a priority. The successful candidate may come from any subfield of political science or public policy, but their research should feature some computational social science component such as natural language processing, network science, machine learning, etc. The successful candidate will be expected to teach courses in political methodology as well as courses in their area of research specialization at all levels of the curriculum (lower and upper division undergraduate and graduate).  
 
Assistant Professor of Econometrics and Statistics - Booth School of Business - University of ChicagoLetters: Jake, Michelle  Deadline: October 1, 2024  Delivery: Interfolio (after shortlist?)  Notes: Only CV and JMP required to apply.  
 
Assistant Professor in Quantitative Social Science Methods - Center for Socio-Political Data - Sciences PoLetters: Jake, Michelle  Deadline: October 1, 2024  Delivery: After shortlist?  Notes: Chair Emiliano Grossman. (S)he should have completed a PhD in social sciences; her/his work and research should concentrate on the analysis of political attitudes, institutions, or policies with a strong and visible emphasis on quantitative methods and a methods-focused research agenda. A comparative research agenda will be appreciated.
